concepts.title: Financial System Functions
concepts.desc: Achieve purposes: save, borrow, raise equity, manage risk, exchange assets, trade on information.

concepts.title: Asset Classifications
concepts.desc: Securities (stocks, bonds), Currencies, Commodities, Real assets, Contracts (forwards, futures, options, swaps).

concepts.title: Financial Intermediaries
concepts.desc: Brokers (match buyers/sellers), Dealers (trade from inventory), Exchanges (organized markets), ATS (dark pools).

concepts.title: Short Selling
concepts.desc: Borrow and sell security, buy back later. Profit if price falls. Unlimited loss potential. Margin requirements apply.

concepts.title: Leverage
concepts.desc: Margin buying: borrow to buy securities. Amplifies both gains and losses. Margin call if equity falls below maintenance.

concepts.title: Order Types
concepts.desc: Market (execute immediately at best price), Limit (specify max buy/min sell price), Stop (triggered at price level).

concepts.title: Market Efficiency
concepts.desc: Prices reflect all available information. Weak (past prices), Semi-strong (public info), Strong (all info including private).

formulas.name: Leverage Ratio
formulas.where: Higher leverage = more risk and potential return

formulas.name: Margin Call Price
formulas.formula: P<sub>call</sub> = P<sub>0</sub> Ã— (1 - Initial Margin) / (1 - Maintenance Margin)

decisions.question: Market order vs Limit order?
use: Market: when speed of execution matters more than price
Limit: when price certainty matters more than speed
avoid: Market orders in illiquid securities (wide bid-ask can hurt)
Limit orders that are too far from market (may never execute)

pitfalls: Short selling has UNLIMITED loss potential (stock can rise infinitely)
Margin call: equity must stay above maintenance margin; forced liquidation otherwise
Market orders guarantee execution but NOT price; limit orders guarantee price but NOT execution

examples.title: Margin Call
examples.problem: Buy $10,000 stock with 50% initial margin, 25% maintenance. At what price is margin call triggered?
examples.solution: P<sub>call</sub> = $10,000 Ã— (1-0.50)/(1-0.25) = $5,000/0.75 = $6,667. If stock falls to $6,667, margin call is triggered.

questions.question: A limit buy order at $50 means the order will execute at:
questions.explanation: A limit buy specifies the maximum price. The order executes at $50 or lower â€” never above the limit.

questions.question: The maximum loss on a short sale is:
questions.explanation: A short seller loses when the stock rises, and there is no upper limit on stock prices. Loss potential is theoretically unlimited.

questions.question: A dealer differs from a broker in that a dealer:
questions.explanation: Dealers buy and sell from their own inventory, earning the bid-ask spread. Brokers only match buyers with sellers for a commission.

concepts.title: Price-Weighted Index
concepts.desc: Weight by share price (e.g., DJIA). Higher-priced stocks have more influence. Affected by stock splits.

concepts.title: Market-Cap Weighted
concepts.desc: Weight by market value (e.g., S&P 500). Larger companies dominate. Free-float adjusted: exclude closely held shares.

concepts.title: Equal-Weighted Index
concepts.desc: Equal weight to each stock. Must rebalance periodically. Small-cap tilt vs cap-weighted.

concepts.title: Rebalancing & Reconstitution
concepts.desc: Rebalancing: adjusting weights. Reconstitution: changing index membership. Both affect tracking portfolios.

formulas.name: Price-Weighted Index
formulas.where: Divisor adjusted for splits and changes

formulas.name: Market-Cap Weighted Return
formulas.where: w<sub>i</sub> = market cap<sub>i</sub> / total market cap

decisions.question: Which weighting method to prefer?
use: Cap-weighted: most common, investable, represents market portfolio
Equal-weighted: more diversified, no concentration risk
avoid: Cap-weighted for active strategies (overweights overvalued stocks)

pitfalls: Price-weighted indexes are biased toward high-price stocks regardless of company size
Cap-weighted indexes can be dominated by a few mega-cap stocks
Stock splits affect price-weighted but NOT cap-weighted indexes

questions.question: In a price-weighted index, a stock split will:
options: Require an adjustment to the divisor
questions.explanation: A split reduces the stock's price (reducing its weight) and requires a divisor adjustment to keep the index level unchanged.

questions.question: Market-capitalization weighted indexes are biased toward:
questions.explanation: Cap-weighted indexes give more weight to stocks with higher market caps, which may include overvalued stocks (momentum bias).

concepts.title: Efficient Market Hypothesis (EMH)
concepts.desc: Security prices fully reflect all available information. Prices adjust rapidly to new information.

concepts.title: Weak Form
concepts.desc: Prices reflect all past market data. Technical analysis cannot earn excess returns.

concepts.title: Semi-Strong Form
concepts.desc: Prices reflect all publicly available info. Neither technical nor fundamental analysis earns excess returns.

concepts.title: Strong Form
concepts.desc: Prices reflect ALL info including private/insider info. Even insiders cannot earn excess returns (not supported empirically).

concepts.title: Market Anomalies
concepts.desc: January effect, size effect, value effect, momentum, post-earnings announcement drift. May be real or data-mining artifacts.

concepts.title: Behavioral Finance
concepts.desc: Loss aversion, overconfidence, herding, information cascades. Investor psychology can create mispricings.

decisions.question: Implications for investment strategy?
use: Weak efficient: fundamental analysis can work, but not technical
Semi-strong: only insider info gives edge; use passive strategies
Strong efficient: no analysis adds value; index everything
avoid: Assuming perfect efficiency â€” real markets have frictions

pitfalls: Most evidence supports weak and semi-strong efficiency, NOT strong form
Anomalies may disappear once published (arbitraged away)
Behavioral biases can cause temporary mispricings but may not be easily exploitable

questions.question: Under the semi-strong form of EMH:
options: Technical analysis can generate excess returns
Fundamental analysis can generate excess returns
Only insider information can generate excess returns
No information can generate excess returns
questions.explanation: Semi-strong: all public info is priced in. Only private/insider info could provide an edge (but trading on it is illegal).

questions.question: The post-earnings announcement drift anomaly suggests that:
options: Stock prices adjust slowly to earnings surprises
questions.explanation: PEAD shows that stocks continue to drift in the direction of earnings surprises for weeks/months, contradicting semi-strong efficiency.

concepts.title: Common Shares
concepts.desc: Residual claim, voting rights, dividends not guaranteed. Represents ownership. Risk: last in liquidation.

concepts.title: Preference Shares
concepts.desc: Fixed dividend, priority over common. Cumulative: missed dividends accumulate. Participating: share in excess earnings.

concepts.title: Depository Receipts (DRs)
concepts.desc: ADRs: US-listed foreign stocks. GDRs: listed outside the company's home country. Sponsored vs unsponsored.

concepts.title: Private Equity
concepts.desc: Venture capital (early-stage), Leveraged buyouts, Growth equity. Less liquid, longer time horizon.

concepts.title: Return Components
concepts.desc: Capital gain (price appreciation) + Dividend yield. Total return = (P<sub>1</sub> - P<sub>0</sub> + D) / P<sub>0</sub>.

formulas.name: Book Value per Share
formulas.formula: BVPS = (Total Equity - Preferred Equity) / Common Shares Outstanding
formulas.where: Accounting value of equity per share

formulas.name: ROE
formulas.formula: ROE = Net Income / Average Shareholders' Equity

pitfalls: Preference shares are EQUITY but behave like debt (fixed income, priority)
ADRs have currency risk â€” returns depend on both stock performance and exchange rates
Book value per share can differ greatly from market value

questions.question: Cumulative preferred shares ensure that:
options: Missed dividends must be paid before common dividends
The dividend rate increases over time
questions.explanation: Cumulative preferred: any unpaid dividends accumulate and must be paid before common shareholders receive any dividends.

questions.question: ADRs expose investors to:
options: Foreign equity risk and currency risk
No additional risks beyond domestic stocks
questions.explanation: ADRs represent foreign stocks, so investors face both the equity risk of the foreign company and the risk of exchange rate fluctuations.

concepts.title: Business Model Analysis
concepts.desc: Revenue drivers, pricing power, cost structure (fixed vs variable), competitive position.

concepts.title: Revenue Analysis
concepts.desc: Top-down (economy â†’ industry â†’ company) or bottom-up (product-level). Identify volume vs price drivers.

concepts.title: Operating Profitability
concepts.desc: Gross margin, EBITDA margin, operating margin. Trend analysis and peer comparison.

concepts.title: Working Capital Efficiency
concepts.desc: Cash conversion cycle, receivable/inventory/payable days. Links to FSA.

formulas.name: DuPont Analysis (3-part)
formulas.formula: ROE = Net Margin Ã— Asset Turnover Ã— Equity Multiplier

formulas.name: DuPont Analysis (5-part)
formulas.formula: ROE = Tax Burden Ã— Interest Burden Ã— EBIT Margin Ã— Asset Turnover Ã— Leverage

pitfalls: High ROE from leverage is riskier than high ROE from profitability
Compare DuPont components across time and peers to identify drivers of change

questions.question: In 3-factor DuPont analysis, ROE equals:
options: Net Margin Ã— Asset Turnover Ã— Financial Leverage
Gross Margin Ã— Operating Leverage Ã— Tax Rate
questions.explanation: ROE = (NI/Sales) Ã— (Sales/Assets) Ã— (Assets/Equity) = Net Margin Ã— Turnover Ã— Leverage. A and C express the same thing.

modules.title: Equity Valuation: Concepts and Basic Tools

concepts.title: Intrinsic Value
concepts.desc: True worth based on fundamentals. Compare to market price: undervalued if V > P.

concepts.title: Dividend Discount Model (DDM)
concepts.desc: V = Î£ D<sub>t</sub>/(1+r)<sup>t</sup>. Value of stock = PV of all expected future dividends.

concepts.title: Gordon Growth Model
concepts.desc: V = D<sub>1</sub>/(r - g). Assumes constant growth forever. Only works if r > g.

concepts.title: Price Multiples
concepts.desc: P/E, P/B, P/S, P/CF. Quick relative valuation. Compare to peers and history.

concepts.title: Justified P/E
concepts.desc: From Gordon model: Justified P/E = (1-b)/(r-g) where b = retention ratio, g = b Ã— ROE.

concepts.title: Enterprise Value Multiples
concepts.desc: EV/EBITDA: useful for comparing firms with different capital structures. EV = Market Cap + Debt - Cash.

formulas.name: Gordon Growth Model
formulas.where: D<sub>1</sub> = next year dividend, r = required return, g = constant growth

formulas.name: Multi-Stage DDM
formulas.where: V<sub>n</sub> = terminal value using Gordon model

formulas.name: Enterprise Value
formulas.formula: EV = Market Cap + Total Debt - Cash

decisions.question: When to use DDM vs Multiples?
use: DDM: mature dividend-paying companies, when dividends are predictable
Multiples: quick comparison, when detailed forecasting is impractical
EV/EBITDA: comparing firms with different leverage
avoid: P/E when earnings are negative or highly volatile

pitfalls: Gordon model requires g < r (otherwise value is infinite/undefined)
Forward P/E is generally preferred over trailing (more relevant to future)
P/E is meaningless when earnings are negative â€” use P/S or EV/EBITDA instead
High P/E can mean overvalued OR high growth expectations

examples.title: Gordon Growth Valuation
examples.problem: D<sub>0</sub> = $2.00, g = 5%, r = 11%. What is the stock worth?

questions.question: D<sub>1</sub> = $3.00, r = 12%, g = 4%. Stock value per Gordon Growth Model:
The sustainable growth rate equals:
questions.explanation: g = b Ã— ROE, where b = retention ratio (1 - payout ratio). This represents the rate at which earnings can grow using only internally generated funds.

questions.question: Enterprise Value (EV) is best described as:
options: Market cap plus total debt minus cash
Book value of equity plus book value of debt
questions.explanation: EV = Market Cap + Debt - Cash. It represents the total value of the firm to all capital providers.

questions.question: A stock has a P/E of 25 and an expected EPS growth of 20%. The PEG ratio is:
questions.explanation: PEG = P/E / Growth rate = 25/20 = 1.25. PEG < 1 suggests undervalued relative to growth; PEG > 1 suggests potentially overvalued.
